questions.question: She worked ……………………….. and passed the examination.
questions.description: Hard is an adverb. Hardly is also an adverb, but it has a very different meaning. It is similar to scarcely.

questions.question: I am …………………………… about this.
questions.description: Very is normally used without much before adjectives and adverbs.

questions.question: The movie was ……………………….. interesting.
questions.description: Too has a negative meaning. It means more than is necessary or required. So and very are possible here.

questions.question: He …………………………. his father closely.
questions.description: There is no preposition between resemble and its object.

questions.question: Hardly ……………………………. any rest since one week.
questions.description: Hardly is a negative word. When a negative word or expression comes at the beginning of the sentence, it is followed by an inverted word order – that means the auxiliary goes before the subject.

questions.question: That boy does ………………………
questions.description: Mischief is an uncountable noun. We use much to modify it.

questions.question: He is getting ……………………….. day by day.
questions.description: Comparative form of the adjective is preferred here because there is an implied comparison between his present and previous states.

questions.question: If you disturb him, he ……………………………. get angry.
questions.description: In the first conditional, we use a simple present tense in the if-clause and will + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: You had better …………………………… another application.
questions.description: Had better is followed by an infinitive without to.

questions.question: …………………………… across the field, I saw a dead horse.
Rome was ……………………… by Romulus.
questions.description: Found is the past and past participle form of find. Founded is the past participle form of found.

questions.question: His grandfather is ………………………….
questions.description: Dead is an adjective and died is a verb. We need an adjective here because 'is' is a verb of incomplete predication.
